'''Roy Gaines''' (born August 12, 1934)<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p12057/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Roy Gaines |author=Ankeny, Jason |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=September 6, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Oldies">{{cite web |url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-view/Roy-Gaines.html |title=Roy Gaines - Biography |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Oldies.com |accessdate=September 6, 2011}}</ref> is an [[United States|American]] [[Texas blues]] and [[electric blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter.<ref name="Music">{{cite book
| first= Paul
| last= Du Noyer
| year= 2003
| title= The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Music
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Flame Tree Publishing 
| location= Fulham, London
| isbn= 1-904041-96-5
| page= 180}}</ref> Gaines's recorded work includes his self-penned track, "A Hell of a Night", which first appeared on his 1982 [[album]], ''Gainelining''. He is the brother of another blues musician, [[Grady Gaines]].<ref name="AMG"/>

==Biography==
Gaines was born in [[Waskom, Texas]], [[United States]], and relocated with his family to [[Houston]] at the age of six.<ref name="Texas">{{cite book
| first= Alan B.
| last= Govenar
| year= 2008
| title= Texas blues: the rise of a contemporary sound
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Texas A&M University Press 
| location= Texas
| isbn=  978-1-58544-605-6
| page= 297}}</ref> Originally a piano devotee, Gaines moved to playing the guitar in his adolescence.<ref name="AMG"/> In his teens he was acquainted with his fellow budding guitarist, [[Johnny Copeland]].<ref name="Oldies"/> By the age of 14 he had performed onstage backing his hero, [[T-Bone Walker]], and played in the Houston [[nightclub]]s before his move to [[Los Angeles]], [[California]].<ref name="AMG"/> In 1955, Gaines backing work appeared on recordings by [[Bobby Bland]], [[Junior Parker]] and [[Big Mama Thornton]].<ref name="Oldies"/><ref name="Texas"/>  He later backed [[Roy Milton]] and then [[Chuck Willis]], and worked again with Walker.<ref name="Oldies"/>

He released two low-key albums in 1956, and a couple more in the 1960s on small [[record label]]s.<ref name="Oldies"/> In 1966, Gaines became part of [[Ray Charles]]' backing band.<ref name="Texas"/> Other backing work for Gaines included sessions with [[The Everly Brothers]], [[The Supremes]], [[Bobby Darin]], [[Stevie Wonder]], and [[Gladys Knight]].<ref name="Encyc">{{cite book
| first= Gérard
| last= Herzhaft et al
| year= 1997
| title= Encyclopedia of the blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= The University of Arkansas Press 
| location= Fayetteville, Arkansas
| isbn= 1-55728-452-0
| page= 90}}</ref>

His primary function was as a [[sideman]], but he released his solo album, ''Gainelining'' in 1982.  Further works followed such as ''New Frontier Lover'' (2000).<ref name="AMG"/> Also, Gaines had a small part in the 1985 film, ''[[The Color Purple (film)|The Color Purple]]''.<ref name="Encyc"/>  In 2009, Gaines (billed as Roy Gaines & his Orchestra) released ''Tuxedo Blues,'' featuring a full [[big band]].  Selections included "Miss Celie's Blues (Sister)," which Gaines originally performed in ''The Color Purple.''  Also included was a [[cover version|cover]] of [[Michael Jackson]]'s "[[Rock with You (Michael Jackson song)|Rock With You]]."

Gaines' co-composed song, "No Use Crying", has been recorded by [[George Jones]] and Ray Charles.
